sub_title: Researcher on Machine Learning and applications to Integrated Modelling of Fusion Reactors at DIFFER
summary: I am a Scientist and Software Engineer at the Dutch Institute for Fundamental Energy Research. I love to apply my skills in scientific programming and machine learning to fusion energy, but also more general problems, like visualization, pipeline design and more.

education.field_of_study: Science and Technology of Nuclear Fusion

contributors.headline: Researcher on Machine Learning and applications to Integrated Modelling of Fusion Reactors at DIFFER
Researcher on Machine Learning and applications to Integrated Modelling of Fusion Reactors at DIFFER

projects.title: IMASPy
projects.description: DIFFER PhD student Karel van de Plassche came up with a clever approach to improve the system that is crucial for sharing information and performing experiments in the international ITER Organization. Together with the company Ignition Computing and ITER Organization his proof-of-concept has been successfully incorporated in the ITER dynamic Python interface to better store and retrieve sensor data and involved calculations.

contributors.headline: Researcher on Machine Learning and applications to Integrated Modelling of Fusion Reactors at DIFFER
Founder of Ignition Computing, Enjoyn and CTO at Afterservice and Tracklete. Parallel Entrepreneur. PhD in Physics (development of FEM and Monte-Carlo codes for Nuclear Fusion.)

projects.title: Nano PSI
projects.description: An experiment for researching deposition of copper nano particles by a pulsed cascaded arc plasma source.

contributors.headline: Researcher on Machine Learning and applications to Integrated Modelling of Fusion Reactors at DIFFER

profile_positions.description:
Working on cutting-edge projects for large organisations, such as ITER, the world’s largest science experiment, where I have the following tasks:
- Design, develop, test, implement and maintain software applications.
- Manage individual project priorities, deadlines and deliverables.
- Collaborate with colleagues and partner organisations.
- Interact with customers, e.g. by organising technical workshops and training sessions.

Specifically, I am focussing on the IMASPy project; a Pythonic layer to interact with IMAS data.
profile_positions.title: Software Engineer (Visiting)

company.name: DIFFER - Dutch Institute for Fundamental Energy Research

profile_positions.company: DIFFER - Dutch Institute for Fundamental Energy Research
profile_positions.description: Software framework and software model support for the Theory, Simulation, Validation and Verification (TSVV) task 11: Validated Frameworks for the Reliable Prediction of Plasma Performance and Operational Limits in Tokamaks. Advisor to Enabling Research; Theory and Modelling: Development of machine learning methods and integration of surrogate model predictor schemes for plasma-exhaust and PWI in fusion. Maintenance of internal DIFFER codes, for example QuaLiKiz and its neural network derivatives.
profile_positions.title: Junior Researcher (Junior Onderzoeker)

profile_positions.description: Documenting, testing and validating existing (neural network) frameworks for integrated modelling of tokamaks. Consolidation of existing work in preparation of PhD thesis.
profile_positions.title: PHD Student (Visiting, Researcher)

company.name: DIFFER - Dutch Institute for Fundamental Energy Research

profile_positions.company: DIFFER - Dutch Institute for Fundamental Energy Research
profile_positions.description: Working on a post-MSc track to keep developing my research line within DIFFER, the QuaLiKiz Neural Network (QLKNN) physics-based machine learning surrogate model. This has led to an editors pick in AIP Physics of Plasmas: https://aip.scitation.org/doi/10.1063/1.5134126 which is a summary of the development work for the QLKNN-hyper-10D model, which is available open source on qualikiz.com. Future work will continue in a PhD track at TU/e and a short continuation track at DIFFER.
profile_positions.title: Junior Researcher

profile_positions.company: DIFFER - Dutch Institute for Fundamental Energy Research
profile_positions.description: Working on realtime capable first principle based transport modelling in (fusion) plasma's using neural networks. This resulted in a successfully defended MSc thesis. The results can be freely downloaded from the TU/e website, or the qualikiz.com website.
profile_positions.title: Intern

profile_positions.description: Designing software for a high-radix optical Ethernet packet switch. Most of the work consists of working on an embedded Linux system, as well as adjusting and compiling code in C. Other tasks include designing and using higher level applications in Phyton and Java, most in relation to OpenFlow networking.
profile_positions.title: Software Engineer

profile_positions.company: DIFFER - Dutch Institute for Fundamental Energy Research
profile_positions.description:
The FINESSE solver is a Finite Element solver written in FORTRAN used by plasma researchers to reconstruct plasma equilibria in a nuclear fusion reactor. During this internship a visual tool that works hand in hand with FINESSE was designed in Python. This tool, PF2q, uses a quick estimation process to partially bypass FINESSE, making working with FINESSE more convenient and easier. PF2q can be found on GitHub https://github.com/Karel-van-de-Plassche/PF2q.

Excerpt from the final reports abstract:

A problem currently faced by researchers is a mismatch between experimental data, in this case from ASDEX Upgrade, and a software package used to reconstruct plasma equilibrium before a crash, FINESSE. The safety factor proﬁle, also known as q-proﬁle, was used to compare the ASDEX and FINESSE data. Another software package, PF2q, was designed in this report to solve this mismatch. PF2q, using the Grad-Shafranov equation and Finite Element Methods, was able to quickly estimate the q-proﬁle from an input pressure- and F-proﬁles. This was then used to provide the experimenter with a visual tool to make the matching of data easier. PF2q calculates the q-proﬁle within 1% relative error, and was able to estimate the q-proﬁle given input pressure and F radial proﬁles within 1ms.
profile_positions.title: Intern

profile_positions.description:
Abstract of my final report:

Communication systems using copper wiring are increasingly replaced by optical fibre systems to fulfil the ever increasing need for higher bandwidth. To keep up with this need, investigators in the COBRA-institute carry out fundamental research ranging from basic research in physics on novel materials to system applications.

The work described in this report focuses on two devices used in the COBRA research programme: the XFP and the Zarlink transceiver. The XFP is a high speed transceiver that is commonly used for high bit-rate communication in computer networks and telecom links, while the Zarlink TIA/LA transceiver connects photodiodes to the electrical system. The devices have to be configured before they can be used in experiments. The user should be able to control the devices even with little knowledge of software. For this purpose, a control system has been made. The user can control the devices with a computer by using LabVIEW, for which an user-friendly graphical interface has been designed. A separate system using only a keyboard in combination with an LCD screen has been made for when the user only needs basic functionality. The Arduino board was chosen to serve as a link between the computer and the stand-alone version. It communicates with the XFP board via I2C and with the Zarlink transceivers via a two-wire interface. The user interface has been constructed in LabVIEW, to provide the user a user-friendly graphical interface, while its modular design ensures future programmers will be able to improve the current software. 

The software has been written to give the user full control over the devices. At this moment, the software has not been sufficiently tested yet. In future work, the higher level functions should be tested in an experimental environment. However, basic functions of the software have been tested with a positive result, and there are strong indications the higher level functions are working as intended.
